studies.title: Determination of Abundant Metabolite Matrix Adducts Illuminates the Dark Metabolome of MALDI-Mass Spectrometry Imaging Datasets
studies.description: Spatial metabolomics using mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) is a powerful tool to map hundreds to thousands of metabolites in biological systems. One major challenge in MSI is the annotation of m/z values, which is substantially complicated by background ions introduced throughout the chemicals and equipment used during experimental procedures. Among many factors, the formation of adducts with sodium or potassium ions, or in case of matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI)-MSI, the presence of abundant matrix clusters strongly increases total m/z peak counts. Currently, there is a limitation to identify the chemistry of the many unknown peaks to interpret their biological function. We took advantage of the co-localization of adducts with their parent ions and the accuracy of high mass resolution to estimate adduct abundance in 20 datasets from different vendors of mass spectrometers. Metabolites ranging from lipids to amines and amino acids form matrix adducts with the commonly used 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid (DHB) matrix like [M + (DHB-H2O) + H]+ and [M + DHB + Na]+. Current data analyses neglect those matrix adducts and overestimate total metabolite numbers, thereby expanding the number of unidentified peaks. Our study demonstrates that MALDI-MSI data are strongly influenced by adduct formation across different sample types and vendor platforms and reveals a major influence of so far unrecognized metabolite-matrix adducts on total peak counts (up to one third). We developed a software package, mass2adduct, for the community for an automated putative assignment and quantification of metabolite-matrix adducts enabling users to ultimately focus on the biologically relevant portion of the MSI data.

people.affiliation: Max Planck Institute for Marine Microbiology

studyDesignDescriptors.annotationValue: Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption-Ionisation Imaging Mass Spectrometry

publications.title: Determination of Abundant Metabolite Matrix Adducts Illuminates the Dark Metabolome of MALDI-Mass Spectrometry Imaging Datasets.
publications.authorList: Janda M, Seah BKB, Jakob D, Beckmann J, Geier B, Liebeke M.

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
This study is based on 20 MALDI-MSI datasets that were selected with the aim to represent various types of tissue, 2 different matrices and 3 different measurement devices. This included tissue sections of vertebrate brain[1] and urinary bladder[2], marine invertebrates[3], marine and terrestrial plants[4], and chemical standards.


Samples of Bathymodiolus puteoserpentis were collected on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge during the RV Meteor M126 cruise in 2016 at the Logatchev hydrothermal vent field. The specimen was retrieved with the MARUM-Quest remotely operated vehicle (ROV) at the Irina II vent site at 3038 m depth, W44°58’43.98’’.


Samples of Bathymodiolus childressi were collected at the Northern Gulf of Mexico during the RV Nautilus cruise NA58 in 2015. The specimen was retrieved with a remotely operated vehicle (ROV) from a cold seep site at 1078 m depth, N28°7’28.92’’ and W89°8’27.959’’.


Samples of Bathymodiolus azoricus were collected at the MAR, Menez Gwen, Woody during the BioBaz cruise in 2013. The specimen was retrieved with a remotely operated vehicle (ROV) from a hydrothermal vent site at 828 m depth, N37°50’40.3559’’ and W31°31‘09.1981’’.


After samples were retrieved, the gills were dissected, snap frozen in liquid nitrogen on board and stored at -80 °C until use.


Sea grass samples were collected in the Mediterranean Sea at the island of Elba.


Mouse brain samples were kindly provided by the University of Bremen, snap frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80 °C until use.


Theobroma cocoa seeds were kindly provided by the Jacob University Bremen, snap frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80 °C until use.


Refs:

[1] Soltwisch J, Kettling H, Vens-Cappell S, Wiegelmann M, Müthing J, Dreisewerd K. Mass spectrometry imaging with laser-induced postionization. Science. 2015 Apr 10;348(6231):211-5. doi:10.1126/science.aaa1051. Epub 2015 Mar 5. PMID:25745064

[2] Römpp A, Spengler B. Mass spectrometry imaging with high resolution in mass and space. Histochem Cell Biol. 2013 Jun;139(6):759-83. doi:10.1007/s00418-013-1097-6. Epub 2013 May 8. PMID:23652571

[3] Geier B, Sogin EM, Michellod D, Janda M, Kompauer M, Spengler B, Dubilier N, Liebeke M. Spatial metabolomics of in situ host-microbe interactions at the micrometre scale. Nat Microbiol. 2020 Mar;5(3):498-510. doi:10.1038/s41564-019-0664-6. Epub 2020 Feb 3. PMID: 32015496

[4] Dopstadt J, Vens-Cappell S, Neubauer L, Tudzynski P, Cramer B, Dreisewerd K, Humpf HU. Localization of ergot alkaloids in sclerotia of Claviceps purpurea by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry imaging. Anal Bioanal Chem. 2017 Feb;409(5):1221-1230. doi:10.1007/s00216-016-0047-2. Epub 2016 Nov 21. PMID:27873003

protocols.name: Preparation
protocols.description:
The metabolite mix was created from 20mM stock solutions in water (Aminomethylphosphonate, Carnitine, Cellobiose, Citric acid, Cytidine, Dimethylsulfoniopropionic acid, Dodecanoic acid, Folic acid, Glucose, Glucose-6-phosphate, Glycine, Leucine, Maleic acid, Mannitol, N-Acetylglucosamine, Nonanoic acid, Phenylalanine, Phosphoglyceric acid, Phosphonoacetic acid, Pyruvic acid, Ribose, Thymine, Urea). The mix was spotted onto a Polysine slide with a pipette and left to dry. 


All tissue samples were submerged in precooled 2% w/v carboxymethyl cellulose gel (CMC, MW ~ 700,000, Sigma-Aldrich GmbH) and snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen. Embedded samples were cross-sectioned with a thickness of 10-16 mM with a cryostat (Leica CM3050 S, Leica Biosystems Nussloch GmbH). Individual sections were thaw-mounted onto coated Polysine slides (Thermo Scientific) and subsequently frozen in the cryostat chamber. Slides with tissue sections were stored in slide containers within a desiccator with silica granules, to prevent air moisture condensation on the tissue upon removal from the freezer.


To apply the matrices, we used 2 different spraying instruments:

An ultrafine pneumatic sprayer system with N2 gas (SMALDIPrep, TransMIT GmbH, Giessen, Germany)[1] was used for bathymodiolin tissue samples (see sample list) to deliver 100 μL of a 30 mg/mL solution of 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid (DHB, Sigma-Aldrich, Steinheim, Germany) dissolved in acetone/water (60:40 v/v) containing 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) to the sample[2].


A SunChrom SunCollect System was used to deliver a Cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid (CHCA) in a solution of 5 mg/mL in acetonitrile/water (70:30 v/v) containing 2% TFA and 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid in a solution of 30 mg/ml in methanol/water (50:50 v/v) containing 0.1% TFA to remaining samples. The matrices were sprayed in a meandering movement covering the whole slide (~15 cm2) with a line distance of 2 mm. For DHB, 10 layers have been delivered to the slide (1. Layer: 10 μL/min, 2.-10. Layer: 15 μL/min) and for CHCH, 8 layers have been delivered to the slide (1. Layer: 10 μL/min, 2. Layer: 20 μL/min, 3.-8. Layer: 30 μL/min).


To locate the field of view and facilitate laser focusing, a red marker was applied adjacent to the matrix-covered slides. 


Refs:

[1] Kompauer M, Heiles S, Spengler B. Atmospheric pressure MALDI mass spectrometry imaging of tissues and cells at 1.4-μm lateral resolution. Nat Methods. 2017 Jan;14(1):90-96. doi: 10.1038/nmeth.4071. PMID:27842060

[2] Geier B, Sogin EM, Michellod D, Janda M, Kompauer M, Spengler B, Dubilier N, Liebeke M. Spatial metabolomics of in situ host-microbe interactions at the micrometre scale. Nat Microbiol. 2020 Mar;5(3):498-510. doi:10.1038/s41564-019-0664-6. Epub 2020 Feb 3. PMID:32015496

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: The data used was acquired on different MSI setups, including 3 different MALDI sources and 3 detectors (atmospheric pressure, 337 nm of laser, AP-SMALDI10, Orbitrap (Q Exactive Plus); high-vacuum, 337 nm, MALDI2, QTOF (Synapt G2-S), HDMS; high-vacuum, 355 nm, SmartBeam-II, MRMS (solariX)) (for full information see Table S2, S3 in the paper associated with this study). MSI datasets referred to as ‘this study’ were acquired with an AP-SMALDI10 setup using an atmospheric pressure matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization ion source (“AP-SMALDI10”, TransMIT GmbH, Germany), coupled to a Q ExactiveTM HF mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific GmbH, Bremen, Germany). MS images were collected with a specified step size (see Table S3 in the paper associated with this study) and without overlapping of the laser spots. Mass spectra were acquired in positive-ion mode for all sections prepared with CHCA and DHB using different m/z ranges and different mass resolutions (see Table S3 in the paper associated with this study).

protocols.name: Histology
protocols.description: No histology experiments have been performed on samples within this study.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description: After imaging the Thermo *.RAW files were centroided and converted to *.mzML with 'MSConvert GUI' (ProteoWizard, v3.0.9810) and then converted to *.imZML using the 'imZML Converter' v1.365. Intensity matrices for this study have been created with 'MSIreader' v0.9, 'SCilS Lab' and an R script which uses 'Cardinal MSI' v2. Peak picking was performed with an R script which uses 'Cardinal MSI' v2.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
Preprocessing of MALDI-MSI datasets:

Peak lists and intensity matrices for datasets 1-3, 5-7, 9, 13-17, 19, 20 were generated with SCiLS v2019b (Bruker, Germany), using 5 ppm bin width. For all details see Table S2 in the paper associated with this study. Peak intensity matrices were exported in text CSV format. Peak lists were filtered to retain those with an intensity threshold 0.05% of the maximum ion intensity of the total ion ≥ chromatogram. Datasets 11 and 12 were processed with Waters Imaging software (HDImaging, Waters), retaining the most intense 4000 peaks of the total ion chromatogram. Datasets 4, 8, 10, 17, 18 were binned with Cardinal MSI v2 at a bin width of 1 mDa, further processing included a 1% frequency filter (default setting) and the threshold of 0.05% top peak intensity[1].


Adduct identification:

Adduct formation increases the ion content and complexity of MALDI-MSI datasets, but results in specific mass differences between parent and adduct ions. For each dataset, possible parent adduct ion pairs were identified in the following way: The mass difference was calculated for all pairs of peaks, and matched against a list of known adduct types[2]-[4] (see Table S1 in the paper associated with this study) within an uncertainty of ± square root((𝑚𝐴𝑝)^2+(𝑚B𝑝)^2)) where 𝑚𝐴 and 𝑚B are the parent and adduct masses and 𝑝 is the mass accuracy of the processed dataset (see Table S3 in the paper associated with this study). 


Controls for matrix cluster ions and false positives:

To identify DHB matrix-only adduct clusters, three MALDI-MSI measurements were performed on slides containing only Super-DHB (9:1 (w/w) mixture of 2,5-DHB and 2-hydroxy-5- methoxybenzoic acid)(Sigma-Aldrich, Steinheim, Germany), with a combined m/z range of 100-2000. Data were pre-processed in SCiLS as described above with mass accuracy of 5 ppm, and filtered to retain only peaks with intensity threshold 0.05% of the maximum intensity peak. ≥ For each dataset, peaks matching the combined matrix-only peak list within the uncertainty range (calculated as described above) were subtracted. For a true matrix adduct, the parent and adduct ions are expected to be positively spatially correlated. Therefore, for each dataset, Pearson’s two-sided correlation test was performed for all ion pairs using per-pixel intensity values. We applied 3 different methods to screen for false positives: (1) The Bonferroni correction was applied to the p-values from the correlation test and pairs with corrected p ≥ 0.05 were rejected (see all details https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3363065,. (2) Uncorrected p-values for positively-correlated pairs were used for false-discovery-rate analysis with the R package qvalue v2.10.1[5][6] and we applied a q-value cutoff of 10-7 (see https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3363065,). (3) Minimum correlation coefficient cutoff of r > 0.3 was applied directly; the first two methods (Bonferroni-corrected p-values, q-value cutoffs) are effective methods to choose a correlation coefficient cutoff for each dataset (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3363065,)[7]. For data presented in Figure 3 in the paper associated with this study we chose a correlation cutoff of r > 0.1, because it was the most conservative option. To produce the summary plot, the number of putative adducts above the q-value or correlation cutoff for each dataset were tabulated by adduct type as a fraction of the total number of peaks in the mass spectrum and plotted with respect to the instrument platform used to acquire the respective datasets.


Confirmation of adducts by on-tissue MS2 measurements

Conformation of selected annotated ions was done via on-tissue MS fragmentation. A consecutive tissue section of dataset 1 was covered with Super-DHB by spraying 30 mg/ml Super-DHB in 60:40 acetone:H2O (vol./vol.) with 0.1% formic acid onto the sample using the TransMIT matrix sprayer (TransMIT, Gießen). The matrix was sprayed for 30 min with a N2 flow of 5 L/min and a liquid flow of 7.5 μL/min. Afterwards the slide was shortly placed into a petri dish with a drop of methanol for recrystallization. A 1 Dalton isolation window and a resolution of 240,000 at m/z 200 at the mass range 100-900 m/z were used for MALDI-MS2 experiments with the AP-SMALDI10 setup. The sample was manually screened for the presence of target ion with a laser energy of 6.5 µJ. For each mass spectrum ions of 30 laser pulses were accumulated in the ion trap, before they were fragmented with a collision energy of 15 eV via HCD (higher energy collisional dissociation). 100 spectra were averaged using Xcalibur Qual Browser v3.0.63 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Bremen).


No metabolite identification was applied. Adduct identification has been performed with 'mass2adduct'.


Ref:

[1] Bemis KD, Harry A, Eberlin LS, Ferreira C, van de Ven SM, Mallick P, Stolowitz M, Vitek O. Cardinal: an R package for statistical analysis of mass spectrometry-based imaging experiments. Bioinformatics. 2015 Jul 15;31(14):2418-20. doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btv146. Epub 2015 Mar 15. PMID:25777525

[2] Petković, M.; Schiller, J.; Müller, M.; Süß, R.; Arnold, K.; Arnhold, J., Zeitschrift für Naturforschung B, 2009, 64 (3), 331-334

[3] Jourdan F, Breitling R, Barrett MP, Gilbert D. MetaNetter: inference and visualization of high-resolution metabolomic networks. Bioinformatics. 2008 Jan 1;24(1):143-5. doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btm536. Epub 2007 Nov 14. PMID:18003642

[4] Breitling R, Ritchie S, Goodenowe D, Stewart ML, Barrett MP. Ab initio prediction of metabolic networks using Fourier transform mass spectrometry data. Metabolomics. 2006;2(3):155-164. doi:10.1007/s11306-006-0029-z. Epub 2006 Jul 25. PMID:24489532

[5] Mukaka, M. M., Malawi medical journal : the journal of Medical Association of Malawi, 2012, 24 (3), 69-71

[6] Storey, J. D. (2003). The positive false discovery rate: A Bayesian interpretation and the q-value. Annals of Statistics, 31(6), 2013–2035

[7] R. S. Brown, N. L. Gilfrich. Maximum-Likelihood Restoration Data Processing Techniques Applied to Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Mass Spectra. Applied Spectroscopy 1993, 47 (1) , 103-110
